heading: Title
text: The Boring World of Phase-Transfer Catalysis

heading: Abstract
text: The use of phase-transfer catalysis in organic synthesis has been recognized as a versatile method for many years. Asymmetric phase-transfer catalysis, which uses structurally well-defined chiral catalysts, has become a topic of great scientific interest over the past three decades. Although various effective chiral catalysts have been reported and utilized for practical asymmetric transformations, the design and development of new chiral phase-transfer catalysts remain attractive research subjects in organic chemistry due to the high utility and practicability of phase-transfer-catalyzed reactions. This review focuses on recent examples of newly designed effective chiral phase-transfer catalysts.

heading: Introduction
text: Phase-transfer catalysis is a versatile method for organic synthesis that is widely used in both industry and academia. It is characterized by simple experimental operations, mild reaction conditions, inexpensive and environmentally friendly reagents and solvents, and the ability to conduct large-scale preparations in process chemistry. Asymmetric phase-transfer catalysis, which uses chiral, non-racemic catalysts, has become a topic of great scientific interest over the past three decades. Cinchona alkaloid-derived tetraalkylammonium salts are the pioneering and most reliable chiral phase-transfer catalysts. Recently, bifunctional catalysts with an amide or urea moiety have been developed, demonstrating the possibility of new catalyst design. Binaphthyl-modified tetraalkylammonium salts and TADDOL-derived and/or multicyclic onium salts have also been effective chiral phase-transfer catalysts. Crown ethers are another type of representative chiral phase-transfer catalysts. Anion phase-transfer catalysis with chiral phosphoric acid catalysts is a new concept in phase-transfer catalysis developed by Toste.

heading: Review
text: The article discusses the use of lipophilic, bulky chiral phosphate anions as a means to bring the normally insoluble cationic fluorinating agent, selectfluor, into solution for use in asymmetric fluorinations. Chiral carboxylic acid was also found to be an effective anionic phase-transfer catalyst. While these chiral phase-transfer catalysts have allowed for efficient and useful asymmetric transformations, there is still a need for further design and development of new chiral phase-transfer catalysts in organic chemistry. The article concludes by summarizing recent examples of newly designed effective chiral phase-transfer catalysts. A representative image of chiral phase-transfer catalysts is also included.

heading: Amino Acid-Derived Catalysts
text: The article discusses the design of new chiral phase-transfer catalysts, specifically 1,2,3-triazolium catalysts of type 22. These catalysts were prepared from α-amino acids via copper(I)-catalyzed Huisgen 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition of amino acid-derived azides with terminal alkynes. The catalyst ability of 22 was examined in asymmetric phase-transfer alkylation of oxindole derivative 24a, and it was found that the double hydrogen-bonding by the triazolium C(5)-H proton and the amide N-H proton of 22 to anion is essential to achieve highly enantioselective reactions. Further fine-tuning of the catalyst 22 improved the enantioselectivity, and the highly selective reaction was achieved by the use of optimized catalyst 22b. The new chiral 1,2,3-triazolium catalysts 22 could also be applied to other asymmetric phase-transfer reactions.

heading: Highly Enantioselective Reactions Catalyzed By Chiral 2-Oxopyrimidinium Salt Catalysts In Phase-Transfer Chemistry
text: The paper discusses various asymmetric transformations achieved through the use of different catalysts. The Mannich reaction of cyanosulfone 26a and asymmetric alkylation of cyanosulfone 26b were achieved with catalysts 22c and 22d, respectively, resulting in good enantioselectivity. The ring-opening reaction of racemic 2,2-disubstituted aziridine 29 and 3-substituted oxindole 24a with catalyst 22 under phase-transfer conditions was also examined, resulting in high diastereo- and enantioselectivity. Catalyst 22e efficiently promoted the reaction. Phase-transfer cyanation of alkylideneindolenine, generated in situ from sulfonylalkylindole 31, under the influence of catalyst 22f to obtain product 32 was also reported. Catalyst 33, a phenylglycine-derived chiral 2-oxopyrimidinium salt catalyst, was developed and used in the highly enantioselective conjugate addition of glycine derivative 34 with methyl vinyl ketone to obtain α-amino acid derivative 35. The paper emphasizes the importance of fine-tuning catalysts to achieve efficient asymmetric transformations.

heading: Scheme 3 Chiral 2-Oxopyrimidinium Salt Catalyst.
text: The paper discusses the use of chiral bifunctional catalysts in highly enantioselective phase-transfer reactions. The catalysts, which possess a thiourea or urea moiety, were used in asymmetric addition reactions to obtain products with good enantioselectivity. Bifunctional tetraalkylammonium bromide was used to promote the addition reaction of thiophenol to imine precursor, resulting in a product with good enantioselectivity. Aza-Henry reaction was also achieved using the catalyst. Another chiral bifunctional quaternary ammonium salt possessing a urea moiety was developed and used in asymmetric phase-transfer alkylation of azlactone to obtain α,αdialkyl-α-amino acid derivative with high enantioselectivity. The paper includes a diagram of the chemical structures of the catalysts and the products obtained.

heading: Scheme 4
text: The article discusses the development of chiral bifunctional quaternary ammonium and phosphonium salts with thiourea or urea moieties. The authors designed and synthesized four different bifunctional phosphonium bromide catalysts, each with a different moiety, and tested their effectiveness in various asymmetric reactions. The catalysts were found to be effective in promoting asymmetric conjugate addition, asymmetric desymmetrization, asymmetric aza-Henry reaction, and asymmetric cyclization. The bifunctional design of the catalysts was essential in achieving highly enantioselective reactions. The authors conclude that these chiral bifunctional phosphonium salts have potential applications in various organic transformations.

heading: Chiral Diamine-Derived Catalysts
text: The paper discusses the development of various chiral catalysts for asymmetric phase-transfer reactions. Ooi and colleagues developed a P-spiro chiral tetraaminophosphonium salt catalyst that can be used for the enantioselective alkylation of azlactone, leading to the synthesis of α,α-dialkyl-α-amino acids and peptides containing quaternary stereogenic carbon centers. Tan and colleagues developed chiral pentanidium salt catalysts that can be used for the conjugate addition of glycine derivatives, asymmetric oxidation of oxindole derivatives, and the synthesis of chiral sulfoxides. They also developed a chiral bis-guanidinium salt catalyst for asymmetric oxidation reactions. Waser and Massa et al. developed chiral bifunctional tetraalkylammonium salt catalysts that can be used for asymmetric fluorination and aldol-initiated cascade reactions. The fine-tuning of the R groups on nitrogen in these catalysts was found to be essential for achieving highly enantioselective phase-transfer reactions.

heading: Chiral Phosphine-Derived Catalysts
text: The paper discusses the development of chiral quaternary phosphonium bromides as phase-transfer catalysts for catalytic asymmetric synthesis. The use of commercially available chiral phosphine compounds as catalyst precursors allows for the construction of a catalyst library of chiral quaternary phosphonium salts with various structures. After optimization of the catalyst library, the bifunctional catalyst of type 68 was found to be effective for asymmetric conjugate addition and sulfenylation reactions. The reaction was efficiently promoted by phosphonium bromide 68a with low catalyst loading under base-free neutral phase-transfer conditions to give the product in high yield and enantioselectivity. The study highlights the importance of developing effective chiral phosphine compounds as ligands for metal catalysts to establish practical asymmetric reactions.

heading: Scheme 12
text: The paper discusses the development of chiral bifunctional phosphonium salts as catalysts for asymmetric conjugate addition and sulfenylation of 3-aryloxindoles. The design of chiral bifunctional phosphonium bromides with a hydroxy group was expanded to include new chiral bifunctional phosphonium bromides with an amide or urea moiety. The ability of the new bifunctional phosphonium salts possessing an amide moiety was examined in the asymmetric sulfenylation of β-keto ester and the asymmetric chlorination of β-keto esters under base-free neutral phase-transfer conditions. The results showed that the tunable acidity of an amide moiety of the catalyst could open up further possibilities for realizing other types of asymmetric transformation using these bifunctional catalysts. The paper also discusses the development of chiral quaternary phosphonium salts-catalyzed asymmetric nucleophilic aromatic substitution (S N Ar) reaction under phase-transfer conditions. The newly-designed chiral bifunctional quaternary phosphonium bromide possessing a urea moiety gave a product in high yield and enantioselectivity due to the interaction of the urea moiety with nitroarene through double hydrogen-bonding.

heading: Conclusion
text:
In the field of organic chemistry, the use of phase-transfer catalysis has long been recognized as a versatile method for organic synthesis. Over the past three decades, there has been a growing interest in asymmetric phase-transfer catalysis, which utilizes chiral catalysts to achieve enantioselective reactions. While various effective chiral catalysts have been developed, there is still a need for the design and development of new chiral phase-transfer catalysts.

Recent research has focused on the design of chiral phase-transfer catalysts derived from amino acids, 2-oxopyrimidinium salts, bifunctional catalysts with thiourea or urea moieties, and chiral phosphine-derived catalysts. These catalysts have shown promising results in achieving highly enantioselective reactions in various asymmetric transformations.

The findings of this study highlight the importance of fine-tuning catalysts to achieve efficient asymmetric transformations. The development of new chiral phase-transfer catalysts opens up possibilities for further advancements in organic chemistry and the synthesis of complex molecules.

Future research in this field could explore the synthesis and application of novel chiral catalysts, as well as the optimization of existing catalysts to improve their efficiency and selectivity. Additionally, the study of the mechanism of chiral phase-transfer catalysis could provide valuable insights for the development of new catalysts and the understanding of asymmetric reactions.

Overall, the emergence of next-generation chiral phase-transfer catalysts revolutionizes asymmetric synthesis, offering new opportunities for the synthesis of chiral compounds and the advancement of organic chemistry.

heading: References
